ETYMOLOGY: From Old English wīf ('woman, female'), of Germanic origin. Originally referred to any woman, later specialized to mean 'married woman' in the 13th century.

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: Noun: A word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A married woman considered in relation to her spouse.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 一个已婚的女性，相对于她的配偶而言；妻子，太太。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: He took his wife and daughter on a trip to the coast.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 他带着他的妻子和女儿去了一趟海岸旅行。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: vtr: Transitive verb: a verb that requires a direct object.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: (Informal or slang) To take (a woman) as a wife; to marry.
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: After years of dating, he finally decided to wife her.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 经过多年的约会，他最终决定娶她。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: Noun: A word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: (In compounds, archaic) A woman, regardless of her marital status. (Reflects the older meaning of the word.)
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: （用于复合词，古语）泛指女性；妇人。（例如 fishwife 意为“卖鱼妇”）
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The fishwife was known for her loud and aggressive bargaining.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 那位卖鱼妇以其大声且咄咄逼人的议价方式而闻名。
